I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Following the successful completion of technical assistance (TA) for Capacity Building 
for  Gender  Mainstreaming  in  Agriculture  in  2008,  the  Government  of  the  Lao  People’s 
Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  asked  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  provide 
additional  TA  for  strengthening  capacity  in  gender-integrated  planning,  monitoring,  and 
evaluation in agriculture and forestry.1 An ADB reconnaissance mission visited Vientiane 15–19 
March 2010 to consult with the Government of the Lao PDR and key stakeholders2 on the 
identification of problem areas and how a follow-up TA might address remaining capacity issues. 
A draft TA concept paper was prepared in response to the request. A fact-finding mission was 
fielded in Vientiane 2–6 August 2010 to finalize the objectives and scope of the TA, and the 
formulation and implementation of issues of the proposed TA for Capacity Strengthening for 
Gender  Mainstreaming  in  the  Agriculture  Sector.  The  government  confirmed  the  impact, 
outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference of the proposed TA. The TA is included in ADB’s country strategy and program 
midterm review 2007–2011 for the Lao PDR.3 The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The agriculture sector contributes 39% to the Lao PDR’s gross domestic product and 
employs 80% of its predominantly agrarian population. Although women account for 54% of the 
agricultural  workforce,  they  receive  a  disproportionately  small  share  of  the  services  and 
resources directed at agricultural and rural livelihoods. Despite their significant contribution to 
the national economy, women's roles in agriculture and forestry tend to remain mostly invisible 
and unaccounted for in public policies and programs. Gender gaps in the agriculture sector exist 
in (i) agriculture extension services; (ii) cultivation, commercialization, and other productivity 
enhancement interventions; (iii) market information; and (iv) financial services. Gender bias in 
service delivery is the product of a wider, more systemic bias in the agriculture sector’s planning, 
monitoring, and evaluation model that reduces sector performance. Gender inequality has a 
direct bearing on poverty reduction, given women’s high level of participation in a variety of 
agricultural activities. To promote agriculture productivity, gender inequalities in rural service 
delivery will have to be addressed. The Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MAF) can therefore 
play a central role in reducing gender disparities and rural poverty.  
 
3.  This  TA  builds  on  the  experience  of  other  ADB-funded  TA  projects  on  gender 
mainstreaming in the region (Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam). The TA projects for both 
Cambodia4 and Lao PDR focused on institutional setup, systems, and procedures; provision of 
gender-analysis training to agriculture sector personnel; and enhancement of women farmers’ 
access to agriculture extension services. The TA for Viet Nam5 focused its support on the 
preparation of a gender-mainstreaming planning handbook for the Ministry of Agriculture and

2         
Rural Development (MARD); the provision of sex-disaggregated targets for the existing MARD 
plan;  guidelines  on  planning  and  monitoring  with  sex-disaggregated  targets;  and  training 
curriculum support for MARD and the National Agriculture Extension Center. This TA goes 
further  by  functionally  integrating  the  government’s  gender-mainstreaming  mechanism—the 
Division for the Advancement of Women (DAW)—directly with central, provincial, and district 
planners in routine planning, monitoring, and evaluation exercises, and by providing gender-
mainstreaming  support  to  the  preparation  of  the  MAF  Strategy  for  Agriculture,  Natural 
Resources and Rural Development 2020. The key lesson from previous TA projects is that 
capacity building needs to be integrated into existing projects to provide tangible results. This 
TA will pilot a gender-integrated planning approach in nine provinces and selected districts in 
the Lao PDR. 
 
4.  The TA will support human resource and technical capacity development for gender-
integrated planning, monitoring, and evaluation of the agriculture sector. As such, the TA falls 
under the country strategy and program midterm review 2007–20116 pillar III goals to support 
both  the  ability  of  public  officials  and  the  capacity  of  selected  sectors  to  develop  sector 
strategies and improved budgeting, planning, and management capabilities in ministries for 
which  ADB  is  providing  support.  The  TA  is  in  line  with  the  National  Growth  and  Poverty 
Eradication Strategy (2006), the National Strategy for the Advancement of Women (2006–2010), 
and MAF’s Resolution for Gender Mainstreaming (2008). 
  
5.  Discussions with MAF identified the following gaps and shortcomings: (i) gender has not 
been integrated into the planning cycle, (ii) gender-integration activities occur in development 
partner-funded projects without coordination with or links to MAF central planning and resource 
allocation processes, and (iii) statistics and information related to gender are dispersed and not 
coordinated to inform systematic planning. The TA responds to the three areas needing support.  
 
6.  Gender has not been integrated into the planning, monitoring, and evaluation cycle. 
Development partners, including the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), the 
Netherlands Development Organization, the Swedish International Development Cooperation 
Agency, and the World Bank, have supported area- or department-specific planning manuals for 
their projects. As with information systems and gender strategies, planning approaches tend to 
be guided by project-specific outcomes and are not coordinated by MAF. The lack of uniform 
performance  indicators  makes  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  gender  mainstreaming  in  the 
agriculture sector difficult. Training manuals on gender mainstreaming and area- and project-
specific participatory planning are abundant in MAF. However, manuals, guidelines, and tools 
for gender-integrated planning, monitoring, and evaluation methods are lacking. It is, therefore, 
necessary  to  strengthen  the  effectiveness  of  MAF’s  Department  of  Planning  and  line 
department  planners  and  DAW  staff  with  training  support  in  gender-integrated  planning 
approaches for their day-to-day activities. Because MAF is shifting toward a program-based 
approach (Overseas Development Assistance Program Planning Unit), the TA is timely in its 
intent to align aid policies, strategies, and resources with a standardized gender-integrated 
planning, monitoring, and evaluation approach to be applied to all MAF programs and projects. 
 
7.  Gender-integration  activities  occur  in  development  partner-funded  projects  without 
coordination with or links to MAF central planning and resource allocation processes. Despite 
the establishment of DAW, it is not consulted regarding the development of sector strategy. 
Further, Sub-CAW (Commission for the Advancement of Women) members of line department 
levels have yet to be involved in MAF’s project planning processes and inception meetings. 
While DAW is well positioned in the MAF organizational hierarchy (Permanent Secretary’s 
                                                 
6  ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy Midterm Review: Lao People’s Democratic Republic, 2007–2011. Manila.

3
Office [PSO]), with an established gender network from the central (Sub-CAW  secretariat, 
department-level Women’s Advancement Unit), provincial (Provincial Agriculture and Forestry 
Office deputy director as head of the Women's Advancement Unit), and district levels (gender 
focal  points),  it  lacks  the  operational  tools  to  mainstream  gender  in  MAF’s  systems  and 
frameworks. DAW’s coordination effectiveness urgently needs to be strengthened through the 
development of a gender-responsive MAF strategy, master plan, and investment plan to enable 
it to exercise its mandated authority to mainstream gender in MAF.  
 
8.  Statistics and information related to gender are dispersed and not coordinated to inform 
systematic planning. Sex-disaggregated data, if it is collected at all, tends to be intervention-
specific,  which  is  symptomatic  of  the  lack  of  coordination  across  existing  projects  and 
agriculture sector activities. Hence, the utilization of indicators to plan, budget, monitor, and 
evaluate gender-responsive agriculture sector delivery and gender-inclusive resource allocation 
between men and women farmers is weak. MAF’s Center for Statistics and Information, the 
Department of Statistics in the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI), and a range of 
development partners are involved in managing the information needed for planning in the 
agriculture sector and collecting data for different purposes and audiences. Communication and 
sharing of information appears limited and needs coordination. Strengthening and rationalizing a 
uniform management information system (MIS) to inform gender-responsive planning in the 
agriculture sector will require collaboration and coordination of the various stakeholders.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be the effective implementation of a gender-sensitive MAF 
strategy and action plan. The expected outcome of the TA will be the effective integration of 
gender issues into MAFs plans, programs and projects. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will produce three main outputs: (i) a gender-sensitive MAF strategy and action 
plan; (ii) gender-responsive MIS and MAF annual plans with sex-disaggregated targets; and (iii) 
a pilot application of gender-integrated planning, monitoring, and evaluation in nine provinces—
five  provinces  (Attapeu,  Champasack,  Saravan,  Savannakhet,  and  Xekong)  under  the 
Sustainable Natural Resource Management and Productivity Enhancement Project (SNRMP)7 
and four provinces (Bokeo, Luang Namtha, Oudomxai, and Phongsali) under the Northern Rural 
Infrastructure Development Project (NRIDP).8 In operational terms, the TA will institutionalize 
the functional mechanisms in place for replicating and achieving a cascading effect for other 
ADB projects. 
 
11.  Output 1: Gender-sensitive strategy and action plan for MAF. MAF is preparing a 
sector strategy,9 to be followed by a master action plan,10 and MAF investment plan.11 Because

4         
of the urgent timelines, ADB will separately recruit a staff consultant to assist MAF’s strategy 
formulation  team12 with  integrating  gender  elements  into  the  MAF  strategy.13 A  gender-
mainstreaming and integrated-planning specialist will provide support to the master action plan 
and MAF investment plan. The TA will support MAF in preparing a gender-responsive MAF 
strategy and master plan; drafting gender-integrated planning manuals; training MAF planners 
and DAW staff in gender-integrated planning, monitoring, and evaluation; and coordinating 
between MAF’s gender-mainstreaming network14 and MAF’s Planning Department in planning, 
monitoring, and evaluation. Sustainability of gender mainstreaming will be ensured by the MAF 
strategy, acting as a platform for other development partners to lend assistance in pre-identified 
and gender-responsive interventions. 
 
12.  Output 2: Gender-responsive MIS and MAF annual plans with sex-disaggregated 
targets. The TA will support the development of a gender-responsive MIS and an organizational 
mechanism for the MIS to inform annual planning processes undertaken by MAF’s Department 
of Planning with support from DAW. Both the specialist on sex-disaggregated data and the 
gender-responsive MIS specialist will be responsible for taking stock of sex-disaggregated data 
and developing uniform indicators to monitor the gender impact and performance of MAF’s 
strategy and action plan, programs, and projects to achieve the output.  
 
13.  Output  3:  Gender-integrated  plans  and  monitoring  and  evaluation  system 
prepared by MAF planners and DAW network staff in nine pilot provinces. While outputs 1 
and  2  will  provide  the  platform  for  gender-integrated  planning,  monitoring,  and  evaluation, 
output 3 will provide the working tools. These include the preparation of a consolidated gender-
integrated planning manual and training of Sub-CAW and MAF provincial and district planners. 
To achieve sustainability, an organizational mechanism will be developed to coordinate Sub-
CAW  and  provincial  and  district  planners  as  they  undertake  their  gender-mainstreaming 
responsibilities  in  the  implementation  of  MAF’s  strategy  and  action  plan.  Their  functional 
coordination will culminate in the preparation of gender-responsive subproject investments in 
nine pilot provinces. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $500,000  equivalent,  including  contingencies  and 
contributions  from  the  government.  The  government  will  provide  an  in-kind  contribution  of 
$20,000. The government has asked ADB to finance $480,000 equivalent, covering the entire 
foreign-exchange cost. The Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction will finance the TA on a grant 
basis. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. The MAF’s PSO and the Department of 
Planning will be the implementing agencies. The implementing agencies will provide office 
space, counterpart staff, and other services to consultants, and will arrange appointments for 
them  with  relevant  agencies  and  organizations.  The  PSO  will  establish  a  TA  coordination 
committee  (chaired  by  the  MAF’s  PSO)  with  members  from  MAF  departments  (Sub-CAW 
                                                                                                                                                          
11 The MAF investment plan (5-year framework) details the projected type and amount of investments MAF seeks to 
secure to achieve its targets and programs. 
12 The MAF strategy formulation team is coordinated by the Agriculture and Forestry Policy Research Center and 
includes members from MAF line departments. DAW is not represented on the formulation team. 
13 The final draft of the MAF strategy is to be completed by the end of September 2010 for formal presentation to the 
government. 
14 DAW is composed of Sub-CAW members representing each MAF line department.

5
Network) and representatives from the MPI’s Department of Statistics, the Ministry of Finance, 
SNRMP,  and  NRIDP.  DAW  will  be  the  project  coordination  office.  The  TA  coordination 
committee will meet biannually, or more frequently as necessary. The coordination committee 
will endorse the TA work plan before final approval by ADB. 
 
16.  For the pilot application in nine provinces, the TA will coordinate activities with the 
national program coordination units of SNRMP and NRIDP. The participation of the provinces 
covered by SNRMP and NRIDP will be financed under the training component of these two 
projects. Detailed implementation arrangements between the TA and the two projects, including 
supervision arrangements, will be finalized during the TA’s inception phase and later included 
as part of the TA design mechanisms.  
 
17.  The mechanism for DAW and MAF line department staff to coordinate gender-integrated 
planning, monitoring, and evaluation into MAF’s programs and projects will be used as a model 
for replication. Clear operational roles and responsibilities for DAW and MAF line department 
staff will be elaborated during the TA. Hence, in addition to the capacity building outputs, the TA 
intends to provide an operational mechanism for sustainability of gender mainstreaming within 
MAF.  
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from November 2010. The TA will engage 
two international consultants for a total of 10 person-months: a gender mainstreaming and 
integrated planning specialist and team leader (8 person-months) and a gender-responsive MIS 
specialist  (2  person-months).  National  consultants  (14  person-months)  will  be  recruited:  a 
specialist  on  sex-disaggregated  data  (2  person-months)  and  a  gender-planning 
specialist/deputy  team  leader  (12  person-months).  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants is in Appendix 3. The consulting team will be located in DAW. ADB will recruit all 
consultants on an individual basis, in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Funds  for  office  equipment,  workshops,  training, 
seminars, and conferences will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Funds for pilot application 
activities will be managed by SNRMP and NRIDP. 
 
19.  The dissemination strategy will include a mechanism for a custodianship system to 
preserve materials used for gender-integrated planning, monitoring, and evaluation. Training 
materials will be shared with agricultural training institutions such as the National University of 
Lao PDR. The purpose will be to make the materials available in the future and to alert other 
development partners and universities to their existence. Hence, trainers of the next generation 
of planners will imbue them with the gender-integrated approach. The key results and lessons of 
the TA will be disseminated through seminar discussions, the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
briefing materials, and ADB’s website. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $480,000 to the Government 
of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction for Capacity Strengthening for Gender Mainstreaming in the Agriculture 
Sector, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of international and national consultants will be recruited to help the Ministry of 
Agriculture and Forestry (MAF) implement the capacity development technical assistance (TA). 
A total of 10 person-months of international and 14 person-months of national consultants will 
be engaged to implement the TA. Four consultant positions are proposed: two international and 
two national consultants. All consultants will be under the direction of the social development 
specialist of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) assigned to manage the TA. The terms of 
reference  (TOR)  for  the  consultants  are  summarized  in  this  appendix.  Each  international 
consultant will work with a national consultant. The international consultant will be responsible 
for final deliverables and for technical leadership of the respective work streams; the national 
consultants’ TOR will be similar to the international TOR, providing on-the-ground continuity in 
technical focus and implementation. The national consultants will ensure that all relevant data 
are collected and compiled, will provide technical support as directed to address individual 
points of the TOR, and will assist with translation and the engagement and participation of 
provincial and district staff and pilot communities. The detailed TOR follows. 
 
A.   Gender  Mainstreaming  and  Integrated  Planning  Specialist  and  Team  Leader 
(international, 8 person-months, intermittent)  
 
2.  The team leader should have experience in implementing gender-integrated planning, 
monitoring, and evaluation training methodologies and developing gender training materials; an 
understanding of the steps required to develop and implement a gender-mainstreaming strategy 
within an organization; knowledge of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) planning 
processes; and an understanding of rural development issues in Lao PDR.  
 
3.  The team leader will be responsible for overall supervision of the consulting team, 
ensure coordination with host country government agencies and development partners, and 
oversee the development of all TA outputs, in collaboration with the deputy team leader. The 
team leader's management tasks are to: 
 
(i)  develop a detailed work plan for the TA, and prepare an inception report (by the 
end of the first month) that includes the detailed work plan and activity schedule, 
quarterly reports, a midterm report (end of the 12th month), a draft final report 
(end  of  the  23rd  month),  and  a  final  report 2  weeks  after  incorporating  the 
implementing agency’s and ADB’s comments; 
(ii)  monitor and ensure that all activities are carried out on schedule; 
(iii)  identify  key  senior  leaders  and  technical  experts  within  MAF,  Provincial 
Agriculture  Forestry  Extension  Office  (PAFO),  District  Agriculture  Forestry 
Extension Office (DAFO), and the Division for the Advancement of Women (DAW) 
at the national, provincial, and district levels, and work closely with them to 
increase their capacity to act as champions for mainstreaming gender in the 
agriculture sector; 
(iv)  develop and maintain links with appropriate aid agencies and groups working 
with MAF; 
(v)  work closely with DAW and Sub-CAW (Commission for the Advancement of 
Women) members to develop mechanisms and strategies for the development 
and formal adoption of the gender-responsive MAF strategy, master action plan, 
Investment Plan, and gender-responsive management information system (MIS); 
and

10  Appendix 3 
 
(vi)  procure  translators  and  administer  translation  of  reports  and  appendixes  as 
needed. 
 
4.  In collaboration with DAW, the team leader will carry out tasks in two technical areas: 
 
1.  Formulating Gender-Responsive Master Action Plan and Investment Plan 
for the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry 
 
(i)  Use  the  gender-responsive  MAF  strategy1  and  work  with  the  MAF  strategy 
preparation team to facilitate the preparation of a gender-responsive, 5-year MAF 
master action plan and MAF investment plan to guide subproject investment 
opportunities, mechanisms, and entry points in the agriculture sector. The master 
action plan should itemize human and financial resource requirements, including 
the TOR and work plans for MAF Sub-CAW staff at the central, provincial, and 
district levels as an appendix.  
(ii)  Advise the agriculture sector road map strategy formulation team on how to align 
the agriculture sector road map to MAF’s strategy and action plans to ensure that 
it complements ADB’s agriculture sector support program. 
(iii)  Develop a coordination mechanism for provincial and district planners and DAW 
staff to implement the master action plan in planning exercises. 
 
2.  Formulating  Gender-Responsive  Functional  Planning  Manuals  for  the 
Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry 
 
(i)  Review and update previous MAF institutional and human resource inventory 
(under the TA for Capacity Building for Gender Mainstreaming in Agriculture) and 
undertake a needs assessment to inform the preparation of gender-responsive 
functional planning manuals.2 
(ii)  Review  current  and  past  knowledge  products  for  participatory  planning  and 
gender mainstreaming used by staff at the national, provincial, and district levels; 
identify gaps in information and consolidate key best practices and tools for 
integration into gender-responsive planning manuals.  
(iii)  Assist DAW in conducting a consultative stakeholder workshop for planners from 
the MAF Department of Planning, the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) 
Department  of  Planning,  Sub-National  Commission  for  the  Advancement  of 
Women  line  department  gender  focal  points,  and  key  development  partners 
involved in participatory planning-driven projects to identify key planning support 
areas, best practices, and technical gaps for integrating gender, and to promote 
interest in and ownership of the proposed gender-integrated planning approach. 
(iv)  Based on the review and consolidation of existing manuals and the stakeholder 
consultative workshop, prepare a draft gender-responsive planning manual to 
support day-to-day activities of MAF planners. The manual will aim to provide 
practical  guidance  to  implement  MAF’s  strategy  and  master  action  plan  in 
accordance with MAF program and project-planning processes. 
(v)  Working closely with the deputy team leader, assist DAW in conducting regional 
training orientation workshops for provincial and selected pilot district planners 
from MAF’s Department of Planning and Sub-CAW line department gender focal 
                                                 
1  To be prepared in September 2010 with staff consultant budget. 
2  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Capacity Building for Gender 
Mainstreaming in Agriculture. Manila (TA 4655-LAO, approved on 29 September).

Appendix 3  11 
points to implement pilot gender-integrated planning, monitoring, and evaluation 
activities  (along  with  the  Sustainable  Natural  Resources  Management  and 
Productivity Enhancement Project staff in pilot provinces and selected districts). 
(vi)  Evaluate  the  pilot’s  performance  and  identify  mechanisms  for  replicating  or 
expanding it. 
 
B.  Gender-Responsive Management Information Systems Specialist (international, 2 
person-months, intermittent) 
 
5.  The specialist will work closely with the specialist on sex-disaggregated data to establish 
a system for sex-disaggregated data collection and analysis at the central and provincial levels. 
The specialist will 
 
(i)  Review  existing  government  MIS  utilized  by  MAF  (Department  of  Planning) 
Center  for  Statistics  and  Information  and  MPI  Department  of  Statistics  and 
development partner-supported MIS to manage agriculture sector information in 
planning and strategy formulation processes.  
(ii)  Take  stock  of  sex-disaggregated  data  available  to  MAF,  MPI,  National 
Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute and National Agriculture and Forestry 
Extension  Services;  and  identify  gaps,  limits  of  use,  and  application,  where 
relevant.  
(iii)  Review ongoing and past detailed baseline data from ADB and the World Bank 
agriculture support projects and improve TA baseline data. 
(iv)  Identify existing information gaps  and data baseline requirements to  monitor 
progress on gender mainstreaming and the impact of MAF strategies, policies, 
plans,  programs,  projects,  and  organizational  mechanisms  compatible  with 
international  data  standards.  Consult  with  MAF,  MPI,  and  the  Swedish 
International Development Cooperation Agency and the Food and Agriculture 
Organization on current practices in collecting, analyzing, and disseminating sex-
disaggregated data on agriculture and rural development. 
(v)  Assist DAW in conducting a consultative stakeholder workshop for statisticians 
from  MAF’s  Department  of  Planning,  MPI’s  Department  of  Planning,  Sub-
National Commission for the Advancement of Women line department Gender 
Focal Points, and key development partners involved in supporting improved 
data collection and MIS practices to identify key information areas where sex-
disaggregated  data  is,  and  needs  to  be,  routinely  collected  for  planning, 
monitoring, and evaluation.  
(vi)  Develop indicators to monitor gender impact and performance of MAF strategy, 
plan, program, and projects in collaboration with the gender-mainstreaming and 
integrated-planning specialist. 
(vii)  Prepare a draft gender–responsive MIS to support functional activities of MAF 
planners and identify areas requiring further support based on the review and 
consolidation of the existing MIS and stakeholder consultative workshop.  
(viii)  Develop  an  organizational  mechanism  for  gender-responsive  MIS  to  inform 
annual planning processes. 
 
C.  Specialist on Sex-Disaggregated Data (national, 2 person-months, intermittent) 
 
6.  The specialist will work closely with the gender-responsive management information 
specialist to establish a system for sex-disaggregated data collection and analysis at the central 
and provincial levels. The specialist will

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(i)  assess the status of the sex-disaggregated data collection systems at MAF and 
MPI; 
(ii)  review the sex-disaggregated data collected by MAF projects and assess the 
data collection systems; 
(iii)  review  the  sex-disaggregated  data  collected  and  monitored  by  the  MPI 
Department of Statistics; 
(iv)  identify  the  sex-disaggregated  data  required to  assess gender  gaps  in  MAF 
strategies,  policies,  plans,  programs,  and  projects,  and  organizational 
mechanisms  in  consultation  with  MAF  (Department  of  Planning)  Center  for 
Statistics, and in coordination with the team leader; 
(v)  prepare a detailed plan to establish a sex-disaggregated directory and guidelines 
on planning and monitoring with sex-disaggregated targets at MAF; and 
(vi)  prepare a report on the process of system development, outputs, and results, 
part  of  which  will  be  included  in  the  inception,  quarterly,  midterm,  and  final 
reports. 
 
D.  Gender Planning Specialist and Deputy Team Leader (national, 12 person-months, 
intermittent) 
7.  The gender planning specialist will act as the deputy team leader and support the 
activities relating to capacity building and pilot implementation of gender-integrated, planning, 
monitoring, and evaluation at the provincial and district levels and the application of gender-
responsive MIS. During the team leader’s absence, he or she will monitor TA activities on the 
ground and provide inputs to the completion of milestone reports. The consultant's tasks will 
include but not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  providing support to the team leader in assessing and identifying gaps in human 
resource development, knowledge products, and planning strategies required for 
gender mainstreaming in MAF planning processes; 
(ii)  assisting the team leader in designing and developing the training content of a 
gender-responsive  planning  manual  and  field  pilot  application  in  selected 
provinces  and  districts  of  SNRMP  and  the  Northern  Rural  Infrastructure 
Development Project;  
(iii)  working closely with the team leader and other specialists at inception to develop 
a  detailed  work  plan  and  budget  for  the  entire  period  of  the  TA  for  each 
component, and develop monitoring plans and indicators of achievements for the 
deputy team leader to track progress of TA activities; 
(iv)  networking with research and education institutions in agriculture planning and 
gender mainstreaming to develop dissemination mechanisms for consolidated 
TA outputs: a gender-integrated planning manual and gender-responsive MIS;  
(v)  developing  a  dissemination  strategy,  including  a  custodianship  system  to 
preserve  materials  used  for  gender-integrated  planning,  monitoring,  and 
evaluation; and 
(vi)  reviewing translated reports and appendixes to ensure accurate communication 
of technical messages. 
 
E.  Short-Term Trainers, Resource Persons, and Facilitators 
 
8.  Short-term training specialists and resource persons will be engaged as needed to 
conduct subject-specific and technical training. Facilitators will work with PAFOs, DAFOs, and

Appendix 3  13 
DAW to implement pilot activities, including the coordination of follow-up support for training and 
subproject investments. Detailed tasks will be identified and supervised by the team leader 
during TA implementation. General tasks may include the following: 
 
(i)  preparing  training  materials  and  workshop  methodologies,  and  conducting 
subject-specific  workshops  and  seminars  in  MIS  and  planning  for  national, 
provincial, and district planning and implementation staff to develop their capacity 
to mainstream gender issues; 
(ii)  helping PAFO, DAFO, and DAW staff identify, plan, develop, implement, and 
monitor pilot activities; and 
(iii)  preparing training reports, of which summaries and findings will form part of the 
inception, midterm, quarterly, and final reports.
